documents.title: that 's all for today !
text: thanks to everyone who posted questions , and to terry gilliam for so generously staying to answer as many as he could .
until next time !
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:40pm goodbye from me , and thank you for all the interest .
i now return to my lonely , hermit-like existence .
brianshaw001 asks : have you ever considered a really cut-down , raw , basic film production ?
it 'd be great to see your direction and humour without the ( admittedly amazing ) pomp and circumstance .
almost like a beckett play , i suppose .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:39pm well , obviously you 've not seen the zero theorem .
haigin88 asks : did the occupy movement appeal to you , the maker of the crimson permanent assurance from twenty-five years earlier ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:36pm there 's an homage to occupy wall street in the zero theorem .
it was changed slightly to occupy mall street - `` shoppers of the world unite ! ''
occupy was great - people out on the streets protesting against a ridiculous situation .
the thing that surprised me was how long it took the mainstream american news to even start writing about it 's existence .
it was like it did n't exist .
greatcthulhu asks : do you think you will even get to make good omens ?
( because you are the perfect director for it and it would be amazing ) .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:35pm it 's a book that neil gaiman and terry pratchett wrote , which we wrote a screenplay of many years ago .
at the time it was going to star johnny depp and robin williams , sadly johnny was n't a big enough name then .
the script now is in the hands of the receivers of renaissance films who commissioned it .
every time my daughter rings receivers , they refuse to answer .

haigin88 asks : there 's a brilliant story about how you were so furious and nauseated by bush/cheney somehow getting a second term in 2004 that you ripped up all of your us citizenship documents and put all the remnants in the post to the us embassy in london the morning afterwards : is this true ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:33pm no , it 's not true .

but when i went to give up my us citizenship at the us embassy , i used the incorrect word , and it took me some time dealing with the bureaucrat behind the desk that i had to say : i want to renounce my citizenship .
it 's like the scene in brazil where spiro , the maitre 'd , demands jonathan pryce say the number on the menu , when he wants to order a steak .
`` you 'av to say the number !
numero trois ! ''
i found i was in my own film .

pazuzu asks : i 'm sure you get asked this a lot , but is it really frightening to you to see the world of brazil beginning to happen with today 's modern security state , with the constant threat of faceless terrorists used to justify ever greater encroachments on privacy and civil liberties ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:30pm what makes me angry is that i have not been able to sue george w bush and dick cheney for the illegal and unauthorised remake of brazil .

george white asks : was the dalek in kevin 's bedroom in time bandits intentional to reflect the time travel elements of both doctor who and time bandits , the latter of which is the best spiritual adaptation of the former television series ?
i do know that most of the toys were there to reflect his adventures .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:29pm if peter capaldi will forgive me - and the previous doctor whos as well - i have to admit i 'm not a doctor who fan .
britesparc asks : which of your many battles with studios or other filmmaking trials and tribulations would make the best movie in itself ?
brazil ?
fear and loathing ?
don quixote ?

( i mean a drama , by the way , not a documentary ) guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:28pm i think brazil would make a really good one - the script is already written , and as long as they cast somebody very young and incredibly handsome to play me , i will direct it .
imight asks : can you lend me a couple of grand so i can make a doc about some french chaps with cameras from lyon ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:28pm what does that mean ?
britesparc asks : could you ever see yourself signing on as a director-for-hire for a studio ?
i imagine you must get talked about in meetings over stuff like marvel adaptations or fantastic beasts and where to find them .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:26pm fisher king and 12 monkeys , i was a director for hire .
i found being with studios actually easier than raising money independently , and in both instances , the trick is to make sure the two stars are on my side when the movie is finished .
if we remain united , the studio ca n't touch us .

the key is to get the actors to give great performances that they 're proud of , and stay true to the script we signed up for , and avoid all the gadfly interferences from nervous nellie executives who are living in fear that because they greenlit the movie and it failed , theirs would be the heads that would be chopped .
there 's no strategy or plan to getting great performances .
hiring the right people , then creating an environment where they can take chances , and fail , knowing that no-one will see the failures .
if you do n't take chances , you wo n't get great performances .
plus my job is to laugh when they 're funny and cry when they 're tragic - i 'm a good audience .

aussiesamurai asks : what do you think makes the comedy of monty python timeless , the brilliant monty python and the holy grail is celebrating its 40th this year and between my friends and myself would still today be our most quoted movie ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:23pm i have no idea .
and i do n't want to analyse it .
i 'm just happy the money keeps rolling in .
i ca n't explain it - it just works .
i watched it last year and found myself falling about laughing , and i know how the tricks were done .
neuromantic asks : is magical mystery tour the first python film or was python just a beatles spin-off project ?
: p guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:21pm i think magical mystery tour was the last spike milligan film .

harrison asks : in meetings , are you the kind of person who : a ) interrupts people with quotes from films : studio head : so , mr gilliam , we really like your idea mr gilliam : you 're gon na need a bigger boat .

b ) sits in silence , takes it all in , and remains seated for 30 minutes or so after everyone else has left the room c ) lists silly things and doodles guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:21pm i do n't have meetings any more .
nobody wants to talk to me .
and i do n't want to talk to them .

documents.title: `` any company that fires jeremy clarkson from top gear has shot themselves in the foot and i did n't even like top gear ''
text: iampav4advice asks : so many brilliant questions about your films .
thinking of the pythons , many comedians spawn imitators or are succeeded in some way .
with so many fans why do you think there has n't been a new breed of pythons ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:19pm i think python was a very specific chemical combination of six specific people .
and i just think that chemical reaction is very hard to repeat .
but there are plenty of brilliant comedians out there .
i thought the league of gentlemen was a great follow-up python , but again they split up and are all doing different things now .
i also think it has to do with the fact the bbc was very laissez-faire then and allowed us to do what we did in an environment of only three tv channels then - that combination does n't exist .
the bbc has become a very different kind of bureaucracy - john birt created a system of clones of himself who are now running the show .

guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:20pm any company that fires jeremy clarkson from top gear has shot themselves in the foot - and i did n't even like top gear , that 's beside the point .
duncan stockwell asks : do you adhere to any narrative framework the twelve-step monomyth structure for example when writing or directing a film ?
if so , how do you find it helps the process ?
if not , how do you check the film 's pacing ?

guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:17pm no , the only thing i do is get their attention at the beginning , keep them interested during the middle , and send them home with a surprise .
unclearleo asks : is it true that the movie was meant to be called trazil but guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:16pm no - it was originally going to be called 1984 1/2 .
frank64 asks : if you had to make a sequel or prequel to one of your films , which would it be ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:15pm remind me what i 've made i 've forgot .
akakensmith asks : in my memory , correctly or not , there is some sort of ductwork in every scene of brazil , and this relentless but quiet joke is part of the horrifying spine of the film .
i wonder if you could mention another time when you 've created something that works that way meant almost not to be noticed but essential to the vision , the humour , of a film ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:15pm in zero theorem , it is full of religious iconography .

the character cohen lives in a burnt-out chapel , is waiting for a call ; behind him on the alter is a painting of john the baptist baptising jesus , with the holy spirit in the form of a dove , and there are doves flying around if you have n't read the bible , you 'll miss most of these !
taffer92 asks : i have never even heard of you .
how does that make you feel ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:13pm are you a stalker ?
unclezippy asks : is there one art form that makes you particularly happy and who are you favourite illustrators , cartoonists , or artists ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:13pm last night i was at an auction for the bfi , and i met one of my heroes - dave gibbons who illustrated watchmen amongst many other things .
which tells you about the bfi - how the tentacles of cinema spread everywhere , even into the lower-depths world of cartooning .
i spent the whole evening talking to dave .
snarlygog asks : were you influenced by kubrick 's barry lyndon , in lighting the interiors for jabberwocky ?

guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:11pm kubrick was very proud that he lit the interiors of barry lyndon with candelight , and the atmosphere was wonderful - so yes , one tries to get that feeling .

in jabberwocky , the thing for me was getting the smell back into cinema : textures , smells , mud , dirt one of the best things was when we screened it in new york , people were bothered by the filth , the dirty teeth .
one kid was quite aggressive about how terrible i 'd made people look - clearly he 'd never looked in the mirror himself .
jabberwocky was my reaction to american films , the ones with doris day and rock hudson , where everyone was so shiny and scrubbed , they bore no relation to reality .
jjc83 asks : am i right in thinking you once toyed with doing an adaptation of gormenghast and would you ever consider going back to that series ?
are there any other novels you would like to adapt ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:09pm i worked on gormenghast for quite a while , i was completely overwhelmed by mervyn peake .
at one point i was talking to sting about it , and about peter sellars being in it .
it was too expensive to get off the ground , but i stole a lot of ideas from it for jabberwocky .
grannybev : time bandits !
brilliant film .
i saw it as a young adult shared it with my children and their friends and most recently with my eldest grandchild .
watch it every couple of years it never palls .
how do you rate it , terry ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:08pm to me , time bandits was the most important film in my film career , and still is the biggest success i had in america .
it opened the doors to brazil and everything that followed .
what i love the most is it 's full of interesting ideas , exciting enough for adults , and intelligent enough for children .

monstermuse asks : your visual works ala brazil , along with l frank baum 's wizard of oz artwork , the jules verne movie 20,000 leagues under the sea , etc made me aware of and infatuated with steampunk many years ago .
when did you become aware of steampunk , as a genre you 'd already contributed to ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:06pm steampunk was well established before i was aware it existed , and i was very much surprised to see i 'd invented it .
christophertheoboist asks : now that you 've directed two outstanding productions of berlioz operas , when can we expect a third ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:05pm i do n't know .
i honestly do n't .
directing operas in my autumn years is very interesting - to see if i could teach the old dog new tricks .
luckily i was surrounded with really professional people , brilliant professionals , who stopped me from falling on my face .

documents.title: `` heath ledger was capable of anything , and fearless , and a bundle of fun to work with . he would have been the most important actor of his generation ''
text: liam quane asks : what was it like directing heath ledger ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:04pm it was an utter joy .
he was capable of anything , and was fearless , and a bundle of fun to work with .
i really think he would have been the most important actor of his generation .
but the selfish fucker went and died , with no consideration of all the people working on parnassus !
id6108606 asks : were you truly happy with the imaginarium of doctor parnassus , or was it the best you could do in the circumstances ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:03pm it 's better than i could have done under the circumstances !

to be in a situation where the lead actor dies during the film , and being able to finish it because of such love from johnny depp , colin farrell and jude law luckily i was in the position as writer and director to rewrite and redirect .
i still think it 's really good .
it 's not quite as good as i thought at the time , because to actually achieve a finished film that looked the way it had been written was amazing .
i still rate it high on my list of films though .

stephen smith asks : with all the difficulties surrounding the film industry tax brakes , remakes , super hero monopolies and general lack of imagination , are you looking to tv or any of the online content providers as potential outlets for your brand of film making ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 1:01pm yes i am !
we are involved in two possibilities - one , a tv series based on time bandits , another based on a script by richard lagravanese and i wrote after fisher king , called the defective detective .
we 're currently adapting a two hour film into a six hour series .

it 's about a middle aged new york cop who was once a hero who has grown fat and cynical and is in the middle of a breakdown , ending up in a child 's fantasy world where the rules of the mean streets of new york no longer apply .
the best way to kill a dragon is no longer a gun , but a tree branch you think is a sword .
ladynow asks : how would you feel about stage adaptations of your work ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:59pm i would love the idea .
even one of monty python and the holy grail .
sinan ozel asks : can you compare comedy of the 60s-70s with comedy today .
can society still be reflected in comedy ?
has comedy become more universal , if that is not the fact does that say something about globalisation ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:58pm there 's always brilliant comedians out there - all that changes is the public 's perception of them .
in the 70s we were very open minded and could go anywhere - and shock and intimidate .
now people are so afraid of pc , they 're frightened - but there are still great comedians .
louis ck - brilliant , terrifying .
there are people who are not afraid to attack the sacred cows : sex , race , religion or little dogs .

documents.title: `` i love tarantino 's power to be perverse he 's the great film encyclopedist , he 's transforming films into something new and original ''
text: salrush asks : i think your decision to adapt and expand upon chris marker 's wonderful film la jetã©e is likely to have brought a whole host of people to his work who may not have found him otherwise .
are there any other filmmakers you would recommend ?
further to that would you ever consider making a fictional documentary of the kind marker used to make ?
i think you could do something very interesting with that concept .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:55pm chris marker was a genius .
and 12 monkeys is really inspired by his film la jetee , but it was n't a remake , la jetee was the acorn , 12 monkeys was the tree .
one was small , perfectly formed and beautiful ; the other was big and splaying out in all directions .
so i agree - if that leads to discovering marker , we 've done something very important .
but i think probably my attempt to make the man who killed don quixote is a fictional documentary about me .
what 's real and what 's false ?
and will we ever see it ?
i do n't watch films , so i 'm a bad one for recommendations .
have you ever seen quentin tarantino ?
he 's worth watching .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:57pm i love tarantino 's power to be perverse - he 's filmed in 70mm for his new one .
he loves movies more than idea .
all his films are about films .
he 's the great film encyclopedist , he 's transforming films into something new and original .
he 's brilliant .

documents.title: `` it 's amazing how many other directors do n't put up a fight they just bend over . but they 're the ones making movies ''
text: pablo raspberry asks : after twelve monkeys there was a gap before fear and loathing .
do you , in anyway feel the hamster factor was detrimental to getting future projects off the ground ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:52pm no , not detrimental in the least .
the things i was trying to work on just were n't coming together .
hamster factor is worth watching - a great documentary about the process of national research group screenings .
every film that 's made , the public come in and judge , and decisions are made based on these screenings - they 're artificial creations which allow the neuroses of the executives to blossom .
there 's a great scene of me and mick audsley coming out of the screening , the editor , and bubbling because it worked brilliantly .
the next day we have a meeting with the producers and the writers , and found the numbers were n't very good .
what do you do at that point - do you succumb to the people from shopping malls who have seen your film , or do you stick to your guns ?
the only thing we changed was one bit of music that was pushing the romance between bruce and madeleine a little too much , i changed it to something more ambiguous .
the movie went out and made an unbelievable fortune by ignoring the public and the execs .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:52pm it 's amazing how many other directors do n't put up a fight - they just bend over .
but they 're the ones making movies , and i 'm on the street corner
looknlearn asks : the fisher king is a movie that i will always hold in my heart as magical .

two magical lead actors , an oscar winning supporting actress and a story that probably required american audiences , if not all audiences , to extend themselves insomuch as it relies on performances as much as plot .
were you surprised when the movie made a profit ?
are you ever surprised when you films are more than just critical successes or is this aspect of the movie business secondary to what drives you as a maker of magic on screen ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:48pm i was n't surprised it made a profit - it went to number one for five weeks .
the studio was pissed off it did n't make more , but the world series was on .
but it was a big success , the first script i did that i did n't write , and read it , and thought it was extraordinary , the kind of thing i would like to write but was n't capable of .
the cast was genius , but that 's where i spend the most time on films , because if i cast the right people i do n't have to do anything .
six months ago we released a blu-ray of it , and i had to look at it for technical reasons , and was tentative about it because robin williams had just died .
by the end i was grinning like a fool - there was robin , alive , and that 's the film where he 's most like himself .
robin will live forever because of that movie .
haigin88 asks : i 'm very partial to your strange and wonderful film tideland .
could you talk a little about why you decided to make the film ?

guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:44pm mainly because i thought the book written by mitch cullen was the most beautiful tale of a girl on the cusp of puberty , and really testing a child 's resilience .
it was my answer to the endless newspaper stories about child abuse , framing the child as a victim .
the child is made to survive , and if you drop them , they bounce .
it triggered all the responses i thought - people thought the first scene , where a girl cooks heroin for her father , was just about a girl with heroin .
but it was about love , and a role reversal .
people keep discovering it and saying : `` oh , hello ''

documents.title: `` almost every film i begin , i have a scene i really want to make , desperately . and for one reason or another those scenes never get made ''
text: johnnyfingers asks : how much of brazil ended on the cutting room floor and do you regret leaving any scenes out ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:41pm no .
the best scenes in brazil were cut out before we got to the cutting room .

12 weeks into the shoot i realised the film was going to be five hours long and we would be millions of dollars over budget , took two weeks off , and ripped out all my favourite scenes from the script .
almost every film i begin , i have a scene i really want to make , desperately .
and for one reason or another those scenes never get made .
it 's weird , the idea that a particular scene triggers me to make it , literally always ends up not in the film - it 's the sacrificial lamb .
god said abe , kill me a son , i say , where do you want this killing done ?
in brazil , there 's a scene that takes place in this giant stone ship , a castle sized ship and yet it floats , and we could n't afford that , so it ended up what was going on in it .
it involved the day having been purloined by evil , and held inside the ship - sam had to release the day .
it 'll end up in another film
nordlead73 asks : brazil is an incredible film , with an atmosphere that i think could only have been created by hand made sfx .
what are your thoughts on cgi in modern cinema ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:38pm cgi is just another tool - it depends how you use that tool .
i 've used it since baron munchausen , but i disguise it , so you think i 'm doing handmade effects .
fooled ya !
daveid1976 asks : did you enjoy being dead earlier this year ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:38pm i actually did n't know i was dead until i was resurrected .
if only i had known earlier , i would have something intelligent to say about the afterlife .
mark74 asks : dear terry , the adventures of baron munchausen was a gruelling , nightmarish shoot that resulted in a beautiful masterpiece , how do you reflect on it now 25 years later ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:37pm it was a gruelling nightmarish shoot , and it resulted in a beautiful masterpiece .
25aubrey asks : terry , have you ever considered making a completely animated movie ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:36pm yeah , i 've often considered making one , but as long as i can still work with living actors , i prefer live action .
i worked on animation too long during the python years - the loneliness of the cut-out animator
jslblack asks : as a director , do you feel that you have the freedom to make your own choices , when making films , or is this something that happened more so in the past , for you ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:36pm i only make films i have control over .
i make the ultimate choice each time but the ideas are from everyone involved .
i am not an auteur , i am a filteur .
mitra asks : what is your quest ?
what is your favourite colour ?
what is your take on internet trolls ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:35pm internet trolls , what is that ?
the guy under the bridge the billy goats go over ?
they 're the bravest people on the planet , because they actually run away without running .
opinions are cheap and so are trolls .
the first bit was ironic .

documents.title: `` what intrigues me is the fact i 've never worked out what life is , or my job in it ''
text: professorfrankly asks : terry , what has intrigued you most in your life an what still makes you curious ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:33pm what intrigues me is the fact i 've never worked out what life is , or my job in it .
so every day is the first day of this life , the life where i do n't know what it 'll be .

documents.title: `` i do n't want to make a film with an unlimited budget . the limitations make me creative ''
text: bill murray asks : with an unlimited budget what film would you make ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:33pm i do n't want to make a film with an unlimited budget .
the limitations make me creative .
just to spite the producer .

xandra11 asks : i 'm a huge fan of your work and your films and work with the python 's have inspired me over the years to become a creative professional what inspires you and what is the one thing you are most obsessed with creatively at the moment ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:32pm starvation and being homeless inspires .
the fear of that is what inspires me .
my wife says all my films are the same films with different costumes , so clearly i 'm obsessed with that .
id6087845 asks : you 've directed opera and stage as well as cinema but have you considered bringing an operatic piece to cinema ?
either as a concert film or re-imagined as a film .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:31pm for years i wanted to do leonard bernstein 's candide , and when johnny depp was younger i thought he was the perfect candide .
but it never came to fruition ; most of my life has n't come to fruition .
that 's why i 've lived so long .
hey - fruition is 'fruit ion ' - what does that mean ?
callum cormie asks : when choosing your next project , what ideas inspire you the most ?
are there any particular themes that attracts you to a script ?
very big fan by the way .
i even analysed brazil for my dissertation .
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:30pm no scripts have been sent to me for a long time - people only think i work with my own scripts .
how wrong they are .
how lonely i am .
pomsincharge asks : many ( all ? )
of your films seem to employ the same wide angle lens throughout the show .
what 's the thinking behind this , and do you think you 'll ever do it differently ?
guardian contributor terrygilliam 07 october 2015 12:29pm i was only able to purchase one lens , that 's all i 've been able to afford ever since .
until you send me millions of dollars , i 'll be forced to use the same lens on every film .
my paypal account is

text: here he is at the guardian offices , all ready with a list of your questions : beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for terry gilliam
text: as well as silly walks and dead parrots , one of the most enduring elements of monty python is the animation by terry gilliam , full of flapping mouths , giant feet and other madcap collage .
and that freewheeling silliness tinged with something sinister has been at the heart of all of his work since .

his films are fantastical and often dystopian visions , like the nightmarishly intricate worlds of brazil and twelve monkeys , or the steampunk fairy tales time bandits and the imaginarium of doctor parnassus .
some of his projects have n't been realised , like his many failed attempts to film don quixote though that project may once again be back on the cards .
still very much alive despite variety 's recent reports to the contrary , he has now released his illustrated memoir gilliamesque .

to mark its publication , and ahead of a talk event at the south bank , he 's joining us to answer your questions about anything in his life and career , in a live webchat from 12.30pm bst onwards on wednesday 7 october .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The film director and Python has written his autobiography, and he joined us to answer your questions in a live webchat. Catch up with his answers here, from his creative process to his admiration for Tarantino and Heath Ledger.
